Problem:
Consider a heat distribution on a metal rod described by the partial differential equation (PDE) \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = k \\frac{\\partial^2 u}{\\partial x^2}\\), where \\(u(x,t)\\) represents the temperature at point x and time t, and k is the thermal diffusivity. Assess the effect of a heat source represented by a function \\(h(x, t)\\) added at specific points over time.

If a cooling function \\(c(x, t) = -r u\\) (where r is a constant rate of heat removal) is applied as an intervention at a certain time \\(t_1 < T\\), will the temperature distribution \\(u(x, T)\\) be independent of the earlier heat source \\(h(x, t)\\) at t=0?
Explanation: The intervention through \\(c(x, t)\\) changes the system dynamics post-intervention; however, the effect of the earlier heat source \\(h(x, t)\\) at t=0 still influences the temperature distribution up to time \\(t_1\\), and indirectly affects the subsequent evolution of the temperature. Hence, \\(u(x, T)\\) remains dependent on both the initial heat source and the cooling intervention.
